Our Maiden-heads at a higher Rate, our Innocence
Able to make a Mart indeed: we are now too old, Sir,
Perhaps they'll think too Cunning too, and ſlight us,
Beſides, we are altogether unprovided,
Unfurniſh'd utterly of the Rules ſhould guide us:
This Lord comes, licks his Hand; and proteſts to me:
Compares my Beauty to a thouſand fine things;
Mountains and Fountains, Trees and Stars, and Goblins;
Now, have not I the Manners to believe him,
He offers me the honourable Curteſy,
To lie with me all Night, what a Miſery is this?
I am bred up ſo fooliſhly, alas, I dare not,
And how madly theſe things will ſhew there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſend ye not,
Like Parts infected, to draw more Corruption;
Like Spiders to grow great, with growing Evil:
With your own Vertues ſeaſon'd, and my Prayers,
The Card of Goodneſs in your Minds, that ſhews ye
When ye Sail falſe; the Needle touch'd with Honour,
That through the blackeſt Storms, ſtill points at Happineſs.
Your Bodies the tall Barks, rib'd round with Goodneſs;
Your heavenly Souls the Pilots, thus I ſend you;
Thus I prepare your Voyage, Sound before ye,
And even as you Sail through this World's Vanity,
Diſcover Sholes, Rocks, Quickſands, cry out to ye,
Like a good Maſter, tack about for Honour:
The Court is Vertue's School; at leaſt it ſhould be;
Nearer the Sun the Mine lies, the Mettals purer:
Be it granted, if the Spring be once infected,
Thoſe Branches that flow from him muſt run Muddy;
Say, you find ſome Sins there, and thoſe no ſmall ones,
And they like lazy Fits begin to ſhake ye:
Say, they affect your Strength, my happy Children,
Great things through greateſt Hazards are atcheiv'd ſtill.
And then they Shine, then Goodneſs has his Glory,
His Crown faſt rivited, then Time moves under,
Where, through the Miſt of Errors, like the Sun,
Through thick and pitchy Clouds, he breaks out Nobly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir, you have made me half a Soldier,
I will to Court moſt willingly, moſt fondly.
And if there be ſuch ſtirring things amongſt 'em,
Such Travellers into Virginia,
As Fame reports, if they can win me, take me:
I think I have a cloſe Ward, and a ſure one;
A honeſt Mind I hope, 'tis Petticoat-proof,
Chain-proof, and Jewel-proof; I know 'tis gold Proof,
A Coach and Four Horſes cannot draw me from it;
As for your handſome Faces, and filed Tongues,
Curl'd Millers Heads; I have another word for them,
And yet I'll Flatter too, as faſt as they do,
And Lie, but not as lewdly: Come, be Valiant, Siſter,
She that dares not ſtand the puſh o'th' Court, dares nothing,
And yet come off ungrazed: Sir, like you,
We both affect great Dangers now; and the World ſhall ſee
All Glory lies not in Man's Victory.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Mine own Honora.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am very fearful,
Would I were ſtronger Built? you would have me honeſt?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Or not at all, my Viola.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'll think on't.
For 'tis no eaſy Promiſe, and live there.
Do you think we ſhall do well?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Why, what ſhould ail us?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Certain they'l tempt us ſtrongly; beſide the glory
Which Women may affect; they are hanſome Gentlemen,
Every part ſpeaks: Nor is it one Denial,
Nor two, nor ten; from every Look we give 'em,
They'l frame a Hope, even from our Prayers, Promiſes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let 'em feed ſo, and be fat; there is no fear, Wench,
If thou bee'ſt faſt to thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall be:
And your Example will work more. Enter Theod.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not want it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How do you, Sir? Can you lend a Man an Angel?
I hear you let out Money.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Very well, Sir,
You are pleaſantly diſpos'd: I am glad to ſee it,
Can you lend me your patience, and be rul'd by me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Is't come to Patience now?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is't not a vertue?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know nor. I ne're found it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's becauſe
Thy Anger ever knows, and not thy Judgment.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know you have been rifl'd.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nothing leſs, Boy:
Lord, What Opinions theſe vain People publiſh?
Rifl'd of what?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Study your Vertue, patience,
It may get Muſtard to your Meat. Why in ſuch haſte, Sir,
Sent ye for me?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For this end only, Theodore,
To wait upon your Siſters to the Court;
I am commanded they live there.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Toth' Court, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Toth' Court, I ſay.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And muſt I wait upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis moſt fit ye ſhould, ye are their Brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is this the Buſineſs? I had thought your mind, Sir,
Had been ſet forward on ſome noble Action,
Something had truly ſtirr'd ye. Toth' Court with theſe?
Why, they are your Daughters, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: All this I know, Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The good old Woman on a Bed he threw.
To th' Court?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Nor drunk as you are:
Drunk with your duty, Sir: Do you call it Duty?
A Pox o' duty, what can theſe do there?
What ſhould they do? Can ye look Babies, Siſters
In the young Gallants eyes, and twirl their Band-ſtrings?
Can ye ride out to air your ſelves? Pray, Sir,
Be ſerious with me: Do you ſpeak this truly?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, didſt thou never hear of Women
Yet at Court, boy?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes, and good Women too, very good Women,
Excellent honeſt Women; but are you ſure, Sir,
That theſe will prove ſo?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: There's the danger, Brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: God a mercy Wench, thou haſt a grudging of it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now be you ſerious, Sir, and obſerve what I ſay,
Do it, and do it handſomly; go with 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir; I am in no Fault now;
If they be thought Whores for being in my Company;
Pray write upon their backs, they are my Siſters,
And where I ſhall deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye are wondrous Jocund,
But prethee tell me, art thou ſo lewd a Fellow,
I never knew thee fail a truth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am a Soldier,
And ſpell ye what that means.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A Soldier? What doſt thou make of me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your Pallat's down, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar
sp.l: I thank ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come, ſhall we to this matter?
You will to Court?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If you will pleaſe to honour us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'le honour ye, I warrant: I'le ſet yee off
With ſuch a luſtre, Wenches: Alas, poor Viola,
Thou art a Fool, thou crieſt for eating White-bread:
Be a good Houſe-wife of thy Tears, and ſave 'em,
Thou wilt have time enough to ſhed 'em, Siſter.
Do you weep too? Nay, then I'le fool no more.
Come, worthy Siſters, ſince it muſt be ſo,
And ſince he thinks it fit to try your Vertues,
Be you as ſtrong to Truth, as I to guard ye,
And this old Gentleman ſhall have joy of ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene III.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Burris take you ten thouſand of thoſe Crowns,
And thoſe two Chains of Pearl they hold the richeſt,
I give 'em ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Grace;
And may your great Example work in me
That noble Charity to Men more worthy,
And of more Wants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You bear a good mind, Burris;
Take twenty thouſand now; Be not ſo modeſt,
It ſhall be ſo, I give 'em; go, there's my Ring for't.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs your Highneſs ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are honeſt.

div.stage: Enter Alinda, and Putskie at Door.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: They're coming now to Court, as fair as Vertue:
Two brighter Stars ne're roſe here.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Peace, I have it,
And what my Art can do; the Duke —

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I am gone,
Remember. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am counſell'd to the full, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My pretty Miſtreſs, whether lyes your Buſineſs?
How kindly I ſhould take this, were it to me now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs immediately to your Grace,
At this time.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have no Addreſs, I do believe ye,
I would ye had.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Twere too much Boldneſs, Sir;
Upon ſo little Knowledge, leſs deſerving.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You'll make a perfect Courtier.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: a very poor one.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A very fair one, Sweet: come hither to me.
What killing Eyes this Wench has? in his Glory
Not the bright Sun, when the Sirian Star reigns,
Shines half ſo fiery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why does your Grace ſo view me?
Nothing but common Handſomneſs dwells here, Sir,
Scarce that: your Grace is pleas'd to mock my meanneſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not go: I do not lie unto thee,
In my Eye thou appear'ſt —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Dim not the ſight, Sir,
I am too dull an Object.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Canſt thou love me?
Canſt thou love him will honour thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I can love,
And love as you do too: but 'twill not ſhew well:
Or if it do ſhew here where all Light luſtres,
Tinſel Affections, make a glorious gliſtering,
'Twill halt i' th' handſome way.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are ye ſo cunning?
Doſt think I love not truly?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, ye cannot,
You never travell'd that way yet: pray pardon me,
I prate ſo boldly to you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There's no harm done:
But what's your reaſon, Sweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would tell your Grace,
But happily —

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It ſhall be pleaſing to me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I ſhould love you again, and then you would hate me,
With all my Service I ſhould follow ye,
And through all Dangers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This would more provoke me,
More make me ſee thy Worths,
More make me meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You ſhould do ſo, if ye did well and truly.
But though ye be a Prince, and have Power in ye,
Power of Example too, ye have fail'd and falter'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Give me Example where?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You had a Miſtreſs,
Oh Heaven, ſo bright, ſo brave a Dame, ſo lovely,
In all her Life ſo true.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That ſerv'd ye with that Conſtancy, that Care,
That lov'd your Will, and woo'd it too

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That nurs'd your Honour up, held faſt your Vertue;
And when ſhe kiſs'd encreas'd, not ſtole your Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And I neglected her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Loſt her, forſook her,
Wantonly flung her off.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What was her Name?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her Name as lovely as her ſelf, as noble,
And in it all that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her Name was Beau-deſert
Do you know her now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Beau-deſert? I not remember —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I know you do not:
Yet ſhe has a plainer Name; Lord Archas Service;
Do you yet remember her? there was a Miſtreſs!
Fairer than Women, far fonder to you, Sir,
Than Mothers to their firſt-born Joys: Can you love?
Dare you profeſs that Truth to me a Stranger,
A thing of no Regard, no Name, no Luſtre,
When your moſt noble Love you have neglected,
A Beauty all the World would woo and honour?
Would you have me credit this? think ye can love me,
And hold ye conſtant, when I have read this Story?
Is't poſſible you ſhould ever favour me,
To a ſlight Pleaſure prove a Friend, and faſt too,
When, where you were moſt ty'd, moſt bound to benefit,
Bound by the Chains of Honeſty and Honour,
You have broke and boldly too? I am a weak one,
Arm'd only with my Fears: I beſeech your Grace
Tempt me no further.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who taught you this Leſſon?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Woful Experience, Sir: If you ſeek a Fair one,
Worthy your Love, if yet you have that perfect,
Two Daughters of his ruin'd Vertue now
Arrive at Court, excellent fair indeed, Sir;
But this will be the Plague on't, they're excellent honeſt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I love thy Face.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Upon my Life ye cannot.
I do not love it my ſelf, Sir, 'tis a lewd one,
So truly ill, Art cannot mend it; for if 'twere handſome,
At leaſt if I thought ſo, you ſhould hear me talk, Sir,
In a new Strain; and though ye are a Prince,
Make ye petition to me too, and wait my Anſwers;
Yet, o'my Conſcience, I ſhould pity ye
After ſome Ten years Siege.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prithee do now.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What would ye do?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why I would lye with ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I do not think ye would.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: In troth I would, Wench.
Here, take this Jewel.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Out upon't that's ſcurvy.
Nay, if we do, ſure we'll do for good Fellowſhip,
For pure Love, or nothing: thus you ſhall be ſure, Sir,
You ſhall not pay too dear for't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure I cannot.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By'r Lady but ye may: when ye have found me able
To do your Work well, ye may pay my Wages.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why does your Grace ſtart back?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I ha' ſeen that ſhakes me:
Chills all my Blood: O where is Faith or Goodneſs?
Alinda thou art falſe, falſe thou fair one,
Wickedly falſe; and (woe is me) I ſee it.
For ever falſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am glad 't has taken thus right. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'll go ask my Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whether I ſhall lye with you, or no: If I find her willing—
For look ye, Sir, I have ſworn, while I am in her Service—
('Twas a raſh Oath I muſt confeſs.)

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou mockeſt me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, would you lye with me, if I were willing?
Would you abuſe my Weakneſs?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would piece it,
And make it ſtronger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Highneſs,
When you piece me, you muſt pice me to my Coffin:
When you have got my Maiden-head, I take it,
'Tis not an Inch of an Ape's Tail will reſtore it;
I love you, and I honour you; but this way
I'll neither love nor ſerve you:
Heaven change your Mind, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And thine too:
For it muſt be chang'd, it ſhall be. Exit.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Boroskie, Burris, Theodore, Viola, and Honora.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They are goodly Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are,
Wondroos ſweet Women both.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Does your Lordſhip like 'em?
They are my Siſters, Sir; good luſty Laſſes,
They'll do their Labour well, I warrant you
You'll find no Bed-ſtraw here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank you, Brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: this is not ſo ſtrongly built; but ſhe is good Mettle,

Of a good ſtirring ſtrain too: ſhe goes tith, Sir.
Enter 2 Gent.
Here they be, Gentlemen, muſt make you merry,
The Toys you wot of: do you like their Complexions?
They be no Moors: what think you of this Hand, Gentlemen?
Here's a white Altar for your Sacrifice:
A thouſann Kiſſes here. Nay, keep off yet, Gentlemen,
Let's ſtart firſt, and have fair Play: what would you give now
To turn the Globe up, and find the rich Moluccas?
To paſs the Straights? Here (do you itch) by St. Nicholas,
Here's that will make you ſcratch and claw,
Claw my fine Gentlemen, move you in divers ſorts:
Pray you let me requeſt you to forget
To ſay your Prayers, whilſt theſe are Courtiers;
Or if you needs will think of Heaven, let it be no higher
Than their Eyes?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How will you have 'em beſtow'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Even how your Lordſhip pleaſe,
So you do not bake 'em.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Bake 'em!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are too high a Meat that way, they run to Gelly.
But if you'll have 'em for your own Diet, take my Counſel,
Stew 'em between two Feather-beds.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Pleaſe you, Colonel,
To let 'em wait upon the Princeſs?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes, Sir,
And thank your Honour too: But then happily,
Theſe noble Gentlemen ſhall have no acceſs to 'em;
And to have 'em buy new Cloaths, ſtudy new Faces,
And keep a ſtinking ſtir with themſelves for nothing,
'Twill not be well i'ſaith; they have kept their Bodies,
And bin at charge for Baths: Do you ſee that Shirt there?
Weigh but the moral meaning, 'twill be grievous:
Alas I brought them to delight theſe Gentlemen,
I weigh their wants by mine: I brought 'em wholeſome,
Wholeſome, and young, my Lord, and two ſuch Bleſſings.
They will not light upon again in Ten years.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis fit they wait upon her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are fit for any thing.
They'll wait upon a Man, they are not baſhful,
Carry his Cloak, or untie his Points, or any thing,
Drink drunk, and take Tobacco; the familiar'ſt Fools—.
This Wench will leap over Stools too, and ſound a Trumpet,
Wraſtle, and pitch the Bar; they are finely brought up,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ladies, you are bound to your Brother,
And have much cauſe to thank him:
Ile eaſe you of this Charge, and to the Princeſs,
So pleaſe you, Ile attend 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thank your Lordſhip:
If there be e'er a private Corner as you go Sir,
A fooliſh Lobby out oth' way, make danger,
Try what they are, try.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would fain be your Honours Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are too curſt Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Farewel Wenches, keep cloſe your Ports y'are waſht elſe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Brother beſtow your Fears where they are needful.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Honor thy Name is, and I hope thy Nature.
Goe after, Gentlemen, goe, get a Snatch if you can,
Yond' old Erra Pater will never pleaſe 'em,
Alas I brought 'em for you, but ſee the luck on't,
I ſwear I meant as honeſtly toward ye—
Nay do not cry good Gentlemen: a little Counſel
Will do no harm: they'll walk abroad ith' Evenings,
Ye may ſurprize 'em eaſily, they wear no Piſtols.
Set down your Minds in Metre, flowing Metre,
And get ſome good old Linnen Woman to deliver it,
That has the trick on't: you cannot fail:
Farewel Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have frighted off the Fleſh flies.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Fleſh flies indeed my Lord. Enter a Serv.
And it muſt be very ſtinking Fleſh they will not ſeize on.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip bid me bring this Casket.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes. Cood Colonel
Commend me to your worthy Father, and as a Pledge
He ever holds my Love and Service to him,
Deliver him this poor but hearty Token,
And where I may be his.—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ye are too Noble;
A Wonder here my Lord, that dare be Honeſt,
When all Men hold it Vitious: I ſhall deliver it,
And with it your moſt Noble Love. Your Servant. Ex. Bur.
Were there but two more ſuch at Court, 'rwere Sainted,
This will buy Brawn this Chriſtmas yet, and Muſcadine. Ex.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Ancient, crying Brooms, and after him ſeverally, four Souldiers, crying other things. Borosky and Gentlemen over the Stage obſerving them.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Broom. Broom, the bonny Broom,
Come buy my Birchen Broom,
Ith' wars we have no more room,
Buy all my bonny Broom.
For a Kiſs take two;
If thoſe will not do,
For a little, little Pleaſure,
Take all my whole Treaſure:
If all thoſe will not do't,
Take the Broom-man to boot.
Broom, Broom, the bonny Broom.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: The Wars are done and gone,
And Soldiers now neglected, Pedlars are,
Come Maidens, come alone,
For I can ſhew you handſom, handſome Ware.
Powders for the Hoad,
And Drinks for your Bed,
To make ye blith and bonny.
As well in the Night we Soldiers can fight,
And pleaſe a young Wench as any.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I have fine Potatos,
Ripe Potatos.

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.l: Will ye buy any Honeſty, come away,
I ſell it openly by day,
I bring no forced light, nor no Candle
To cozen ye; come buy and handle:
This will ſhew the great Man Good,
The Tradſman where he ſwears and lyes,
Each Lady of a noble Blood,
The City Dame to rule her Eyes:
Ye are rich Men now: come buy, and then
Ile make ye richer, honeſt Men.

sp.speaker: 4 Sol.
sp.l: Have ye any crackt Maiden-heads, to new leach or mend?
Have ye any old Maiden-heads to ſell or to change?
Bring 'em to me, with a little pritty Gin,
Ile clout 'em, Ile mend 'em, Ile knock in a Pin,
Shall make 'em as good Maids agen,
As ever they have bin.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What means all this, why do y'ſell Brooms Ancient?
Is it Wantonneſs or Want?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: The only Reaſon is,
To ſweep your Lordſhips Conſcience: here's one for the nonce.
Gape Sir, you have ſwallowed many a goodlier Matter—
The only caſting for a crazy Conſcience.

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.l: Will your Lordſhip buy any Honeſty? 'twilt be worth your Money

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.l: Honeſty my Lord, 'tis here in a Quill.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take heed you open it not, for 'tis ſo ſubtle,
The leaſt puff of Wind will blow it out oth'Kingdom.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: Will your Lordſhip taſte a fine Potato?
'Twill advance your wither'd State.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fill your Honour full of moſt noble Itches,
And make Jack dance in your Lordſhips Breeches.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: If your Daughters on their Beds,
Have bow'd, or crackt their Maiden-heads;
If in a Coach with too much tumbling,
They chance to cry, fie, ſo, what fumbling;
If her Foot ſlip, and down fall ſhe,
And break her Leg above the Knee,
The One and Thirtieth of February let this be tane,
And they ſhall be arrant Maids again.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are brave Soldiers; keep your wantonneſs,
A Winter will come on to ſhake this wilfulneſs.
Diſport you ſelves, and when you want your Money — Ex.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Broom, Broom, &c. Exit Singing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You muſt not be ſo fearful, little one,
Nor Lady you ſo ſad, you will ne're make Courtiers
With theſe dull ſullen Thoughts; this Place is pleaſure,
Perſerv'd to that uſe, ſo inhabited;
And thoſe that live here, live delightful, joyful:
Theſe are the Gardens of Adonis, Ladies,
Where all ſweets to their free and noble Uſes,
Grow ever young and courted.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Beſs me Heaven,
Can things of her years arrive at theſe Rudiments?
By your leave fair Gentlewoman, how long have you bin here?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith much about a Week.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You have ſtudied hard,
And by my faith arriv'd at a great Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Were not you baſhful at firſt?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ay, ay, for an Hour or two:
But when I ſaw People laugh'd at me for it,
And thought it a dull Breeding —

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are govern'd here then
Much after the Men's Opinions.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ever Lady

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And what they think is honourable.—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Moſt preciſely
We follow with all Faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A goodly Cathechiſm.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But baſhful for an Hour or two?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith to ſay true.
I do not think I was ſo long: for look ye,
'Tis to no end here, put on what ſhape ye will,
And ſour your ſelf with ne're ſo much Auſterity,
You ſhall be courted in the ſame, and won too,
'Tis but ſome two Hours more; and ſo much time loſt,
Which we hold precious here: In ſo much time now
As I have told you this, you may loſe a Servant,
Your Age, nor all your Art can e'er recover.
Catch me occaſion as ſhe comes, hold faſt there
Till what you do affect is ripn'd to ye.
Has the Duke ſeen ye yet?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What if he have not?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You do your Beauties too much wrong, appearing
So full of ſweetneſs, newneſs; ſet ſo richly,
As if a Council beyond Nature fram'd ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If we were thus? ſay Heaven had given theſe Bleſſings,
Muſt we turn theſe to ſin Oblations?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How fooliſhly this Country way ſhews in ye?
How full of Flegm? do you come here to pray Ladies.
You had beſt cry, ſtand away, let me alone Gentlemen,
Ile tell my Father elſe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This Woman's naught ſure,
A very naughty Woman.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Come, ſay on friend,
Ile be inſtructed by ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Either I or the Devil ſhall: The Duke you were ſpeaking of.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis well remember'd: yes, let him firſt ſee you,
Appear not openly till he has view'd ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: He's a very Noble Prince they ſay.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O wondrous gracious;
And as you may deliver your ſelf at the firſt viewing;
For look ye, you muſt bear your ſelf; yet take heed
It be ſo ſeaſon'd with a ſweet Humility,
And grac'd with ſuch a Bounty in your Beauty—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But I hope he will offer me no ill?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, no:
Tis like he will kiſs ye, and play with ye:

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Play with me, how?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, good Lord, that you are ſuch a Fool now.
No harm aſſure your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Will ye play with me too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Look Babies in your Eyes, my pretty ſweet one:
There's a fine Sport: do you know your Lodgings yet?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I hear of none.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I do then, they are handſome,
Convenient for acceſs.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Acceſs?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes little one,
For Viſitation of thoſe Friends and Servants,
Your Beauties ſhall make choice of: Friends and Viſits:
Do you not know thoſe uſes? Alas poor Novice;
There's a cloſe Couch or two, handſomely placed too.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What are thoſe I pray you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Who would be troubled with ſuch raw things? they are to lye upon,
And your Love by you; and diſcourſe, and toy in.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Alas I have no Love.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You muſt by any means:
You'll have a Hundred, fear not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Honeſty keep me:
What ſhall I do with all thoſe?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll find uſes:
You are ignorant yet, let Time work; you muſt learn too,
To lie handſomly in your Bed a Mornings, neatly dreſt
In a moſt curious Waſtcoat, to ſet you off well,
Play with your Bracelets, Sing; you muſt learn to Rhime too,
And Riddle neatly; ſtudy the hardeſt Language,
And 'tis no matter whether it be Senſe or no,
So it go ſeemly off. Be ſure you profit
In kiſſing, kiſſing ſweetly: there lies a main Point,
A Key that opens to all practick Pleaſure;
Ile help you to a Friend of mine ſhall teach you,
And ſuddenly: your Country way is fulſome.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have you Schools for all theſe Myſteries?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O yes,
And ſeveral Hours prefix'd to Study in:
You may have Kalanders to know the good Hour,
And when to take a Jewel: for the Ill too,
When to refuſe, with Obſervations on 'em;
Under what Sign 'tis beſt meeting in an Arbor,
And in what Bower, and Hour it works; a Thouſand,
When in a Coach, when in a private Lodging,
With all their Vertues.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have you ſtudied theſe?
How beaſtly they become your Youth? how bawdily?
A Woman of your tenderneſs, a Teacher,
Teacher of theſe lewd Arts? of your full Beauty?
A Man made up in Luſt, would loath this in you:
The rankeſt Leacher, hate ſuch Impudence.
They ſay the Devil can aſſume Heavens brightneſs,
And ſo appear to tempt us: ſure thou art no Woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I joy to find thee thus. [aſide

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou haſt no tenderneſs,
No reluctation in thy Heart: 'tis miſchief.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All's one for that; read theſe and then be ſatisfy'd,
A few more private Rules I have gather'd for you,
Read 'em, and well obſerve 'em: ſo I leave you. Exit:

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A wondrous wicked Woman: ſhame go with thee

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What new Pandoras Box is this? Ile ſee it,
Though preſently I tear it. Read thine Viola,
'Tis in our own Wills to believe and follow.

q.l: Worthy Honora, as you have begun
In Vertues ſpotleſs School, ſo forward run.
Purſue that nobleneſs, and chaſte deſire
You ever had, burn in that holy Fire;
And a white Martyr to fair memory
Give up your Name, unſoil'd of Infamy.

sp.l: How's this? Read yours out Siſter: this amazes me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Fear not thou yet unblaſted Violet,
Nor let my wanton words a Doubt beget.
Live in that peace and ſweetneſs of thy Bud,
Remember whoſe thou art, and grow ſtill good.
Remember whoſe thou art, and ſtand a Story
Fit for thy noble Sex, and thine own Glory.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sure a good Woman,
An excellent Woman, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It confounds me;
Let 'em uſe all their Arts, if theſe be their ends,
The Court I ſay breeds the beſt Foes and Friends.
Come, let's be honeſt Wench, and do our beſt ſervice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: A moſt excellent Woman, I will love her. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter Olimpia with a Casket, and Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: MAdam, the Duke has ſent for the two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I prethee go: I know thy Thoughts are with him.
Go, go Alinda, do not mock me more.
I have found thy Heart Wench, do not wrong thy Miſtriſs,
Thy too much loving Miſtriſs: do not abuſe her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your own fair Hands I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: By thy own fair Eyes I underſtand thee too much,
Too far, and build a Faith there thou haſt ruind.
Go, and enjoy thy Wiſh, thy Youth, thy Pleaſure,
Enjoy the Greatneſs no doubt he has promiſed,
Enjoy the ſervice of all Eyes that ſee thee,
The Glory thou haſt aim'd at, and the triumph:
Only this laſt Love I ask, forget thy Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O, who has wrong'd me? who has ruin'd me?
Poor wretched Girl, what poyſon is flung on thee?
Excellent Vertue, from whence flows this Anger?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Go, ask my Brother, ask the Faith thou gav'ſt me,
Ask all my Favours to thee, ask my Love,
Laſt, thy forgetfulneſs of Good: then fly me,
For we muſt part Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are weary of me;
I muſt confeſs, I was never worth your Service,
Your bounteous Favours leſs; but that my Duty,
My ready Will, and all I had to ſerve you—
O Heaven thou know'ſt my Honeſty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: No more:
Take heed, Heaven has a Juſtice: take this Ring with you,
This doting Spell you gave me: too well Alinda,
Thou know'ſt the Vertue in't; too well I feel it:
Nay keep that too, it may ſometimes remember you,
When you are willing to forget who gave it,
And to what Vertuous end.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Muſt I go from you?
Of all the Sorrows ſorrow has—muſt I part with you?
Part with my noble Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Or I with thee Wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And part ſtain'd with Opinion? Farewel Lady,
Happy and Bleſſed Lady, goodneſs keep you:
Thus your poor Servant full of Grief turns from you,
For ever full of Grief, for ever from you.
I have no being now, no Friends, no Country,
I wander Heaven knows whither, Heaven knows how.
No Life, now you are loſt: only mine innocence,
That little left me of my ſelf, goes with me,
That's all my Bread and Comfort. I confeſs Madam,
Truly confeſs, the Duke has often courted me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And powr'd his Soul into thee, won thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do you think ſo?
Well, time that told this Tale, will tell my truth too,
And ſay you had a faithful, honeſt Servant:
The buſineſs of my Life is now to pray for you,
Pray for your Vertuous Loves; Pray for your Children,
When Heaven ſhall make you happy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How ſhe wounds me?
Either I am undone, or ſhe muſt go: take theſe with you,
Some Toys may do you ſervice; and this Money:
And when you want, I Love you not ſo poorly,
Not yet Alinda, that I would ſee you periſh.
Prethee be good, and let me hear: look on me,
I Love thoſe Eyes yet dearly; I have kiſs'd thee,
And now Ile do't again: farewel Alinda,
I am too full to ſpeak more, and too wretched. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have my Faith,
And all the World my Fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: The:
sp.l: I would fain hear
What becomes of theſe two Wenches:
And if I can, I will do 'em good. Enter Gentleman paſſing over the Stage.
Do you hear my honeſt Friend?
He knows no ſuch Name:
What a World of buſineſs,
Which by Interpretation are meer nothing,
Theſe things have here? 'Maſs now I think on't better,
I wiſh he be not ſent for one of them
To ſome of theſe By-lodgings: methought I ſaw
A kind of Reference in his Face to Bawdery.
sp.stage: Enter Gentleman with a Gentlewoman paſſing over the Stage.
sp.l: He has her, but 'tis none of them: hold faſt thief:
An excellent touzing Knave. Miſtreſs
You are to ſuffer your penance ſome half Hour hence now
How far a fine Court Cuſtard with Plumbs in it
Will prevail with one of theſe waiting Gentlewomen,
They are taken with theſe ſoluble things exceedingly;
This is ſome Yeomen oth' Bottles now that has ſent for her,
That ſhe calls Father: now woe to this Ale incenſe.
By your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Well Sir; what's your pleaſure with me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You do not know the way to the Maid's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I Sir,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But you will not tell me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No indeed will not I, becauſe you doubt it. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Theſe are fine Gim-cracks: hey, here comes another,
A Bottle of Wine in's Hand, I take it.
Well met my Friend, is that Wine?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Yes indeed is it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Faith I'll drink on't then.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Ye may, becauſe ye have ſworn, SIr.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis very good, I'll drink a great deal now, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: I cannot help it, Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll drink more yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis in your own Hands.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: There's your Bottle, I thank you.
Pray let me drink again.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Faith but ye ſhall not.
Now have I ſworn, I take it. Fare you well, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is the fin'ſt Place to live in I e'er ente'rd.
Here comes a Gentlewoman, and alone; I'll to her.
Madam, my Lord my Maſter — [Enter Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Who's your Lord, Sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The Lord Boroskie, Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray excuſe me:
Here's ſomething for your Pains: within this hour, Sir,
One of the choice young Ladies ſhall attend him:
Pray let it be in that Chamber juts out to the Water;
'Tis private and convenient: Do my humble Service
To my honourable good Lord, I beſeech you, Sir;
If it pleaſe you to viſit a poor Lady —
You carry the 'haviour of a noble Gentleman,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhall be bold.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis a good Aptneſs in you.
I lye here in the Wood-yard, the blew Lodgings, Sir;
They call me merrily the Lady of the — Sir;
A little I know what belongs to a Gentleman,
And if it pleaſe you take the Pains. [Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dear Lady, take the Pains?
Why a Horſe would not take the Pains that thou requir'ſt now,
To cleave old Crab tree? One of the choice young Ladies!
I would I had let this Bawd go, ſhe has frighted me;
I am cruelly afraid of one of my Tribe now;
But if they will do, the Devil cannot ſtop 'em.
Why ſhould he have a young Lady? are Women now
O' th' Nature of Bottles, to be ſtopt with Corks?
O the thouſand little Furies that fly here now!
How now, Captain?

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: I come to ſeek you out, Sir,
And all the Town I have travell'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's the News, Man?

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: That, that concerns us all, and very nearly:
The Duke this Night holds a great Feaſt at Court,
To which he bids for Gueſts all his old Counſellors,
And all his Favourites: your Father's ſent for.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why he is neither in Coucil, nor in Favour.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: That's it: have an Eye now, or never, and a quick one,
An Eye that muſt not wink from good-Intelligence.
I heard a Bitd ſing, they mean him no good Office.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Art ſure he ſups here?

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Sure as 'tis Day.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis like then:
How now, where haſt thou been, Ancient?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Meaſuring the City:
I have left my Brooms at the Gate here;
By this time the Porter has ſtole 'em to ſweep out Raſcals.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Brooms?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I have been crying Brooms all the Town over,
And ſuch a Mart I have made, there's no Trade near it.
O the young handſome Wenches, how they twitter'd,
When they but ſaw me ſhake my Ware, and ſing too;
Come hither Maſter Broom-man I beſeech you;
Good Maſter Broom-man hither, cries another.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou art a mad Fellow.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: They are all as mad as I: they all have Trades now,
And roar about the Streets like Bull-beggars.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What Company of Soldiers are there?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: By this means I have gather'd
Above a thouſand tall and hardy Soldiers,
If need be, Colonel.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That need's come, Ancient,
And 'twas diſcreetly done: go, draw 'em up preſently,
But without Suſpicion: this Night we ſhall need 'em;
Let 'em be near the Court, let Putskie guide 'em;
And wait me for Occaſion: here I'll ſtay ſtill.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: If it fall out we are ready; if not we are ſcatter'd:
I'll wait you at an Inch.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do, farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are the Soldiers ſtill ſo mutinous?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More than ever.
No Law nor Juſtice frights 'em: all the Town over
They play new Pranks and Gambols: no Man's Perſon,
Of what Degree ſoever, free from Abuſes:
And durſt they do this, (let your Grace conſider)
Theſe monſtrous, moſt offenſive things, theſe Villanies,
If not ſet on, and fed? if not by one
They honour more than you? and more aw'd by him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Happily their own Wants.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: I offer to ſupply 'em.
And every Hour make Tender of their Moneys:
They ſcorn it, laugh at me that offer it:
I fear the next Device will be my Life, Sir;
And willingly I'll give it, ſo they ſtay there.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do you think Lord Archas privy?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More than thought,
I know it, Sir, I know they durſt not do
Theſe violent rude things, abuſe the State thus,
But that they have a Hope by his Ambitions —

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more; he's ſent for?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yes, and will be here ſure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let me talk farther with you anon.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I'll wait, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Did you ſpeak to the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They'll attend your Grace preſently.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How do you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My Eyes are too dull Judges.
They wait here, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be you gone then: Come in, Ladies.
Welcome to th' Court, ſweet Beauties; now the Court ſhines,
When ſuch true Beams of Beauty ſtrike amongſt us:
Welcome, welcome, even as your own Joys welcome.
How do you like the Court? how ſeems it to you?
Is't not a Place created for all Sweetneſs?
Why were you made ſuch Strangers to this Happineſs?
Barr'd the Delights this holds? The richeſt Jewels
Set ne'er ſo well, if they're not worn to wonder,
By judging Eyes not ſet off, loſe their Luſtre:
Your Country Shades are faint; Blaſters of Beauty;
The Manners like the Place, obſcure and heavy;
The Roſe-buds of your Beauties turn to Cankers,
Eaten with inward Thoughts; whilſt there you wander.
Here, Ladies, here, you were not made for Cloiſters,
Here is the Sphere you move in: here ſhine nobly,
And by your powerful Influence command all:
What a ſweet Modeſty dwells round about 'em.
And like a nipping Morn pulls in their Bloſſoms?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your Grace ſpeaks cunningly, you do not this,
I hope, Sir, to betray us; we are poor Triumphs;
Nor can our Loſs of Honour add to you, Sir:
Great Men, and great Thoughts, ſeek things great and worthy,
Subjects to make 'em live, and not to loſe 'em;
Conqueſts ſo nobly won, can never periſh.
We are two ſimple Maids, untutor'd here, Sir;
Two honeſt Maids, is that a Sin at Court, Sir?
Our Breeding is Obedience, but to good things,
To vertuous and to fair: what wou'd you win on us?
Why do I ask that Queſtion, when I have found you?
Your Preamble has pour'd your Heart out to us;
You would diſhonour us; which in your Tranſlation
Here at the Court reads thus; Your Grace would love us,
Moſt dearly love us; ſtick us up for Miſtreſſes:
Moſt certain, there are thouſands of our Sex, Sir,
That would be glad of this, and handſome Women,
And crowd into this Favour, fair young Women,
Excellent Beauties, Sir: When ye have enjoy'd 'em,
And ſuckt thoſe Sweets they have, what Saints are theſe then?
What Worſhip have they won? what Name, you gueſs, Sir,
What Story added to their time, a ſweet one?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A brave ſpirited Wench.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I'll tell your Grace,
And tell you true, you are deceiv'd in us two,
Extremely cozen'd, Sir: And yet in my Eye
You are the handſom'ſt Man I ever lookt on,
The goodlieſt Gentleman; take that hope with you;
And were I fit to be your Wife (ſo much I honour you)
Truſt me I would ſcratch for you but I would have you
I would wooe you then.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She amazes me:
But how am I deceiv'd?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O we are too honeſt,
Believe it, Sir, too honeſt, far too honeſt,
The way that you propound too ignorant,
And there is no medling with us; for we are Fools too,
Obſtinate, peeviſh Fools. If I would be ill,
And had a Wanton's Itch, to kick my Heels up,
I would not leap into th' Sun, and do't there,
That all the World might ſee me: an obſcure Shade, Sir,
Dark as the Deed, there is no truſting Light with it,
Nor that that's lighter far, vain-glorious Greatneſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You will love me as your Friend?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I will honour you,
As your poor humble Handmaid, ſerve and pray for you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What ſays my little one; you are not ſo obſtinate?
Lord, how ſhe bluſhes! here are truly fair Souls:
Come, you will be my Love?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good Sir be good to me,
Indeed I'll do the beſt I can to pleaſe you;
I do beſeech your Grace: Alas, I fear you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What ſhouldſt thou fear?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Fie, Sir, this is not noble.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why do I ſtand entreating, where my Power —

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You have no Power, at leaſt you ought to have none
In bad and beaſtly things: arm'd tnus, I'll die here,
Before ſhe ſuffer wrong.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Another Archas?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: His Child, Sir, and his Spirit.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'll deal with you then,
For here's the Honour to be won: ſit down, Sweet,
Prithee, Honora, ſit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Now ye intreat I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I do, and will deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: That's too much Kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prithee look on me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes, I love to ſee you,
And could look an Age thus, and admire you:
Whilſt you are good and temperate, I dare touch you,
Kiſs your whlte Hand.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why not my Lips?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I dare, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I do not think ye dare.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am no Coward.
Do you believe me now? or now? or now, Sir?
You make me bluſh; but ſure I mean no ill, Sir:
It had been fitrer you had kiſs'd me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That I'll do too.
What haſt thou wrought into me?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I hope all Goodneſs:
Whilſt ye are thus, thus honeſt, I dare do any thing,
Thus hang about your Neck, and thus doat on you;
Bleſs thoſe fair Lights: Hell take me if I durſt not —
But, good Sir; pardon me. Siſter come hither,
Come hither, fear not, Wench; come hither, bluſh not,
Come kiſs the Prince, the vertuous Prince. the good Prince:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Sit down, and hug him ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Fie, Honoira,
Wanton Honoira; is this the Modeſty,
The noble Chaſtity your on-ſet ſhew'd me,
At firſt Charge beaten back? Away.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank you:
Upon my Knees I pray, Heaven too may thank you;
Ye have deceiv'd me cunningly, yet nobly
You have cozen'd me: In all your hopeful Life yet,
A Scene of greater Honour you ne'er acted:
I knew Fame was a Liar, too long, and loud tongu'd,
And now I have found it: O my vertuous Maſter!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My vertuous Maſter too.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Now you are thus,
What ſhall become of me let Fortune caſt for't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'll be that Fortune, if I live, Honoira;
Thou haſt done a Cure upon me, Counſel could not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here take your Ring, Sir, and whom you mean to ruine,
Give it to her next; I have paid for't dearly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A Ring to her?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why frowns my fair Alinda?
I have forgot both theſe again. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Stand ſtill, Sir,
Ye have that violent killing Fire upon you,
Conſumes all Honour, Credit, Faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My Royal Miſtreſs's Favour towards me,
Wo-worth you, Sir, you have poiſon'd, blaſted.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I, Sweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have taken that unmanly Liberty,
Which in a worſe Man is vain-glorious feigning,
And kill'd my Truth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Upon my Life 'tis falſe, Wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ladies,
Take heed, ye have a cunning Gameſter,
A handſome, and a high; come ſtor'd with Antidotes,
He has Infections elſe will fire your Bloods.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prithee, Alinda, hear me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Words ſteept in Honey,
That will ſo melt into your Minds, buy Chaſtity
A thouſand ways, a thouſand Knots to tie you;
And when he has bound you his, a thouſand Ruins.
A poor loſt Woman you have made me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'll maintain thee,
And nobly too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That Gin's too weak to take me:
Take heed, take heed, young Ladies; ſtill take heed,
Take heed of Promiſes, take heed of Gifts,
Of forced feigned Sorrows, Sighs, take heed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By all that's mine, Alinda —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Swear
By your Miſchiefs:
O whither ſhall I go?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Go back again,
I'll force her take thee, love thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Fare you well, Sir,
I will not curſe you; only this dwell with you,
When ever you love, a falſe Belief light on you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: We'll take our leaves too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Part all the World now,
Since ſhe is gone.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are crooked yet, dear Maſter,
And ſtill I fear — Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am vex'd,
And ſome ſhall find it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange
To me to ſee the Court, and welcome:
O Royal Place, how have I lov'd and ſerv'd thee?
Who lies on this ſide, know'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Lord Burris.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou haſt nam'd a Gentleman
I ſtand much bound to.
I think he ſent the Casket, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: An honeſt minded Man, a noble Courtier:
The Duke made perfect Choice when he took him:
Go you home, I ſhall hit the way
Without a Guide now.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You may want ſomething, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Only my Horſes,
Which after Supper let the Groom wait with:
I'll have no more Attendance here.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your Will, Sir? Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are well met here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How now, Boy,
How do'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhould ask
You that Queſtion: how do you, Sir?
How do you feel your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, well and luſty.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What do you here then?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, I am ſent for
To Supper with the Duke.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Have you no Meat at home?
Or do you long to feed as hunted Deer do,
In Doubt and Fear?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have an excellent Stomach,
And can I uſe it better
Than among my Friends, Boy?
How do the Wenches?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They do well enough, Sir,
They know the worſt by this time. Pray be rul'd, Sir,
Go home again; and if you have a Supper,
Eat it in quiet there: This is no Place for you,
Eſpecially at this time,
Take my Word for't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: May be they'll drink hard;
I could have drank my ſhare, Boy.
Though I am old, I will not out.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I hope you will.
Hark in your Ear: the Court's
Too quick of hearing.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not mean me well?
Thou art abus'd and cozen'd.
Away, away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To that end, Sir, I tell you.
Away, if you love your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Who dare do theſe things,
That ever heard of Honeſty?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Old Gentleman,
Take a Fool's Counſel.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis a Fool's indeed;
A very Fool's: thou haſt more of
Theſe Flams in thee, theſe muſty Doubts:
Is't fit the Duke ſend for me,
And honour me to eat within his Preſence,
And I, like a tall Fellow, play at bo-peep
With his Pleaſure?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Take heed
Of bo-peep with your Pate, your Pate, Sir;
I ſpeak plain Language now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If 'twere not here,
Where Reverence bids me hold,
I would ſo ſwinge thee, thou rude,
Unmanner'd Knave; take from his Bounty,
His Honour that he gives me, to beget
Sawcy and ſullen Fears?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are not mad ſure:
By this fair Light, I ſpeak
But what it whiſper'd,
And whiſper'd for a Truth.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A Dog: drunken People,
That in their Pot ſee Viſions,
And turn States, Mad-men and Children:
Prithee do not follow me;
I tell thee I am angry:
Do not follow me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am as angry
As you for your Heart.
I and wilful too: go, like a Woodcock,
And thruſt your Neck ith' nooſe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ile kill thee.
And thou ſpeak'ſt but three words more.
Do not follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A ſtrange old fooliſh Fellow: I ſhall hear yet,
And if I do not my part hiſs at me. Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter two Servants preparing a Banquet.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Believe me Fellow here will be luſty drinking.
Many a waſht Pate in Wine I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.l: I am glad the old General's come: upon my conſcience
That joy will make half the Court drunk. Hark the Trumpet,
They are coming on; away.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: We'll have a Rowſe too. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Archas, Burris, Borosky, attend Gentlemen:

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Come ſeat your ſelves: Lord Archas ſit you there,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis far above my worth.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Ile have it ſo:
Are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: All the Guards are ſet,
The Court Gates ſhut.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then do as I preſcrib'd you.
Be ſure no further.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ſhall well obſerve you.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Come bring ſome Wine: here's to my Siſter Gentlemen;
A Health, and much to all.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pray fill it full Sir.
'Tis a high Health to Vertue: here Lord Burris,
A Maiden Health: you are more fit to pledge it,
You have a Maiden Soul, and much I honour it.
Paſſion o' me, you are ſad Man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How now Burris.
Go to, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take the Rowſe freely.
'Twill warm your Blood, and make you fit for jollity.
Your Graces Pardon: when we get a Cup Sir,
We old Men prate a pace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Mirth makes a Banquet;
As you love me no more.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I thank your Grace.
Give me it; Lord Borosky.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: I have ill Brains Sir.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Damnable ill, I know it.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: But Ile pledge Sir
This vertuous Health. Enter a Servant with Mourning Cloak.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: The more unfit for thy Mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, bring out Robes, and let my gueſts look nobly,
Fit for my Love and Preſence: begin downward.
Off with your Cloaks, take new.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your Grace deals truly
Like a munificent Prince, with your poor Subjects,
Who would not fight for you? what cold dull Coward
Durſt ſeek to ſave his Life when you would ask it?
Begin a new Health in your new Adornments,
The Dukes, the Royal Dukes: ah, what have I got
Sir? ah! the robe of Death!

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You have deſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The Livery of the Grave? do you ſtart all from me?
Do I ſmell of Earth already? Sir look on me,
And like a Man; is this your Entertainment?
Do you bid your worthieſt Gueſts to bloody Banquets.
A Guard upon me too? this is too foul play
Boy to thy good, thine Honour; thou wretched Ruler,
Thou Son of Fools and Flatterers, Heirs of Hypocrites,
Am I ſerv'd in a Hearſe that ſav'd you all?
Are you Men or Devils? do you gape upon me,
Wider, and ſwallow all my Services?
Entomb them firſt, my Faith next, then my Integrity,
And let theſe ſtuggle with your mangy Minds,
Your ſear'd, and ſeal'd up Conſciences, till you burſt.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Theſe words are Death.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No thoſe Deeds that want rewards, Sirrah,
Thoſe Battles I have fought, thoſe horrid Dangers,
Leaner then Death, and wilder then Deſtruction,
I have march'd upon, theſe honour'd Wounds, times Story,
The Blood I have loſt, the Youth, the Sorrows ſuffer'd,
Theſe are my death, theſe that can n'er be recompenc'd,
Theſe that you ſit a brooding on like Toads,
Sucking from my Deſerts the Sweets and Favours,
And render me no pay again but Poiſons.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The proud vain Soldier thou haſt ſet—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt.
Now by my little time of Life lyeſt baſely,
Malitiouſly and loudly: how I ſcorn thee?
If I had ſweld the Soldier, or intended
An Act in Perſon, leaning to diſhonour,
As you would fain have forced me, witneſs Heaven,
Where cleareſt underſtanding of all Truth is,
(For theſe are ſpightful Men, and know no piety)
When Olin came, grim Olin, when his Marches,
His laſt Incurſions made the City ſweat,
And drove before him, as a Storm drives Hail,
Such ſhowers of froſted Fears, ſhook all your Heart-ſtrings;
Then when the Volga trembled at his Terror,
And hid his ſeven curl'd Heads, afraid of bruſing,
By his arm'd Horſes Hoofs; had I been falſe then,
Or blown a treacherous fire into the Soldier,
Had but one ſpark of Villany liv'd within me,
Ye'ad had ſome ſhadow for this black about me.
Where was your ſouldierſhip? why went not you out?
And all your right honourable Valour with you?
Why met you not the Tartar, and defi'd him?
Drew your dead doing Sword, and buckl'd with him?
Shot through his Squadrons like a fiery Meteor?
And as we ſee a dreadful clap of Thunder
Rend the ſtiff hearted Oaks, and toſs their Roots up:
Why did not you ſo charge him? you were ſick then,
You that dare taint my Credit, ſlipt to Bed then,
Stewing and fainting with the Fears you had,
A whorſon ſhaking fit oppreſt your Lordſhip:
Bluſh Coward knave, and all the World hiſs at thee.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Exceed not my command. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Are you gone too? Come weep not honeſt Burris,
Good loving Lord, no more Tears: 'tis not his Malice,
This Fellow's Malice, nor the Duke's Diſpleaſure,
By bold bad Men, crowded into his Nature,
Can ſtartle me: Fortune ne'er raz'd this Fort yet:
I am the ſame, the ſame Man, living, dying;
The ſame Mind to 'em both, I poize thus equal;
Only the Jugling way that told me to it,
The Judas way, to kiſs me, bid me welcome,
And cut my Throat, a little Sticks upon me.
Farwel, commend me to his Grace, and tell him,
The World is full of Servants, he may have many:
And ſome I wiſh him honeſt: he's undone elſe:
But ſuch another doating Archas never,
So try'd and touch'd a Faith: farewel for ever.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Be ſtrong my Lord: you muſt not go thus lightly.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now what's to do? what ſays the Law unto me?
Give me my great Offence that ſpeaks me guilty,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Laying aſide a thouſand petty Matters,
As Scorns and Inſolencies, both from your ſelf and followers,
Which you put firſt fire to, and theſe are deadly,
I come to one main Cauſe, which though it carries
A Strangeneſs in the Circumſtance, it carries Death too,
Not to be pardon'd neither: you have done a Sacrilege.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: High Heaven defend me Man: how, how Borosky?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You have took from the Temple thoſe vow'd Arms,
The holy Ornament you hung up there,
No abſolution of your Vow, no order
From Holy Church to give 'em back unto you
After they were purified from War, and reſted
From Blood, made clean by Ceremony: from the Alta
You ſnatch'd 'em up again, again you wore 'em,
Again you ſtain'd 'em, ſtain'd your Vow, the Church too,
And rob'd it of that right was none of yours Sir,
For which the Law requires your Head, you know it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thoſe Arms I fought in laſt?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: God a Mercy,
Thou haſt hunted out a notable Cauſe to kill me:
A Subtle one: I dye, for ſaving all you;
Good Sir remember if you can, the Neceſſity,
The ſuddainneſs of Time, the Stage all ſtood in;
I was entreated to, kneel'd to, and pray'd to,
The Duke himſelf, the Princes, all the Nobles,
The cries of Infants, bedrid Fathers, Virgins;
Prethee find out a better Cauſe, a handſomer,
This will undo thee too: People will ſpit at thee,
The Devil himſelf would be aſham'd of this Cauſe;
Becauſe my haſte made me forget the Ceremony;
The preſent danger every where, muſt my life ſatisfie?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It muſt and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O baſe ungrateful People,
Have you no other Sword to cut my Throat with
But mine own nobleneſs? I confeſs, I took 'em,
The Vow not yet abſolv'd, I hung em up with:
Wore 'em, fought in 'em, gilded 'em again
In the fierce Tartars Blood; for you I took 'em,
For your peculiar ſafety, Lord, for all,
I wore 'em for my Countries Health, that gron'd then:
Took from the Temple, to preſerve the Temple,
That Holy Place, and all the Sacred Monuments,
The reverent ſhrines of Saints, ador'd and honour'd,
Had been conſum'd to Aſhes, their own Sacrifice,
Had I been ſlack, or ſtaid that Abſolution,
No Prieſt had liv'd to give it; my own Honour
Cure of my Country murder me?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: No, no Sir,
I ſhall force that from you, will make this cauſe light too,
Away with him: I ſhall pluck down that Heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Break it thou may'ſt; but if it bend, for pity;
Dogs and Kites eat it: come, I am Honours Martyr. Exit.

div.head: SCENE VI.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Exceed my Warrant?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know he loves him not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He dares as well meet Death as do it, eat Wildfire;
Through a few Fears I mean to try his goodneſs,
That I may find him fit to wear, here Burris;
I know Borosky hates him, to Death hates him,
I know he's a Serpent too, a ſwoln one Noiſe within.
But I have pull'd his Sting out; what noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Within. Down with 'em, down with the Gates.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Within. Stand, ſtand, ſtand.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Within. Fire the Palace before ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Upon my Life the Soldier, Sir, the Soldier,
A miſerable time is come. Enter Gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O ſave him,
Upon my Knees, my hearts Knees, ſave Lord Archas,
We are undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Dares he touch his Body?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He racks him fearfully, moſt fearfully.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Away Burris,
Take Men, and take him from him; clap him up,
And if I live, I'll find a ſtrange Death for him: Ex. Bur.
Are the Soldiers broke in?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By this time ſure they, are Sir,
They beat the Gates extreamly, beat the People.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Get me a Guard about me: make ſure the Lodgings,
And ſpeak the Soldiers fair.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray Heaven that take Sir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Putsky, Ancient, Soldiers with Torches.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Give us the General, we'll fire the Court elſe,
Render him ſafe and well,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do not fire the Cellar,
There's excellent Wine in't, Captain, and though it be cold weather,
I do not love it mull'd: bring out the General,
We'll light you, ſuch a Bonfire elſe; where are you?
Speak, or we'll toſs your Turrets, peep out of your Hives
We'll ſmoak you elſe: is not that a Noſe there?
Put out that Noſe again, and if thou dar'ſt
But blow it before us: now he creeps out on's Burrough.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Give us the General. Enter Gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, Gentlemen;
Or any thing you can deſire.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: You Musk-cat
Cordevan-skin, we will not take your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Where is the Duke? ſpeak ſuddenly and ſend him hither.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Or we'll ſo fry your Buttocks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good ſweet Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We are neither good, nor ſweet, we are Soldiers
And you Miſcreants that abuſe the General,
Give fire my Boys 'tis a dark Evening,
Let's light 'em to their Lodgings.

div.stage: Enter Olimpia, Honora, Viola, Theodore, Women.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good Brother be not fierce.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I will not hurt her,
Fear not ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: May do what you pleaſe Sir,
I have a Sorrow that exceeds all yours,

And more, contemns all danger.
Enter Duke above.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He's here; what would you Soldiers? wherefore troop ye
Like mutinous Mad-men thus?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Give me my Father.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Anc. Give us our General.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Set him here before us,
You ſee the Pledge we have got; you ſee theſe Torches;
All ſhall to Aſhes, as I live, immediately,
A thouſand lives for one.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But hear me?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l:
No, we come not to diſpute.
Enter Archas and Bur.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: By Heaven I ſwear he's rackt and whipt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O my poor Father!

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Burn, kill and burn.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold, hold I ſay: hold Soldiers,
On your Allegiance hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We muſt not.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold:
I ſwear by Heaven he is a barbarous Traitor ſtirs firſt,
A Villan, and a Stranger to Obedience,
Never my Soldier more, nor Friend to honour:
Why did you uſe your old Man thus? thus cruelly
Torture his poor weak Body? I ever lov'd you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forget me in theſe wrongs, moſt noble Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have blame enough for all my hurts: weep no more Sir,
A Satisfaction for a thouſand Sorrows:
I do believe you innocent, a good Man,
And Heaven forgive that naughty thing that wrong'd me.
Why look you wild my Friends? why ſtare you on me?
I charge you as you are Men, my Men, my Lovers,
As you are honeſt faithful Men, fair Soldiers,
Let down your Anger: Is not this our Soveraign,
The Head of Mercy and of Law? who dares then,
But Rebels ſcorning Law, appear thus violent?
Is this a place for Swords? for threatning Fires?
The Reverence of this Houſe dares any touch,
But with obedient Knees, and pious Duties?
Are not we all his Subjects? all ſworn to him?
Has not he power to puniſh our Offences?
And not we daily fall into 'em? aſſure your ſelves
I did offend and highly, grievouſly,
This good ſweet Prince I offended, my Life forfeited,
Which yet his Mercy, and his old Love met with,
And only let me feel his light Rod this way:
You are to thank him for your General,
Pray for his Life, and Fortune: ſweat your Bloods for him.
You are Offenders too, daily Offenders,
Proud Inſolencies dwell in your Hearts, and you do 'em,
Do 'em againſt his Peace, his Law, his Perſon;
You ſee he only Sorrows for your Sins,
And where his Power might perſecute, forgives you:
For ſhame put up your Swords, for honeſty,
For orders ſake and whoſe you are, my Soldiers,
Be not ſo rude.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They have drawn Blood from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That was the Blood rebel'd, the naughty Blood,
The proud provoking Blood; 'tis well 'tis out Boy;
Give you example firſt; draw out, and orderly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good Brother do

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Honeſt and high Example,
As thou wilt have my Bleſſing follow thee,
Inherit all mine Honours: thank you Theodore,
My worthy Son.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If harm come, thank your ſelf Sir;
I muſt obey you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Captain, you know the way now:
A good Man, and a valiant; you were ever,
Inclin'd to honeſt things: I thank you Captain. Ex. Soul.
Souldiers, I thank you all: and love me ſtill,
But do not love me ſo to loſe Allegiance,
Love that above your lives: once more I thank you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring him to reſt, and let our Cares wait on him;
Thou excellent old Man, thou top of honour,
Where Juſtice and Obedience only build,
Thou ſtock of Vertue, how am I bound to love thee?
In all thy noble ways to follow thee?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Rememember him that vext him Sir,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Remember!
When I forget that Villany, and to pay him
For all his miſchiefs, may all good thoughts forget me

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am very ſore,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring him to bed with eaſe Gentlemen,
For every ſtrip Ile drop a tear to waſh 'em,
And in my ſad Repentance—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
I have a Life yet left to gain that Love Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: HOW do's Lord Archas yet?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But weak an't pleaſe you,
Yet all the helps that Art can, are applied to him;
His Heart's untouch'd, and whole yet; and no doubt Sir,
His Mind being ſound, his Body ſoon will follow.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: O that baſe Knave that wrong'd him, without leave too;
But I ſhall find an Hour to give him thanks for't;
He's faſt I hope?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As faſt as Irons can keep him:
But the moſt fearful wretch—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He has a Conſcience,
A cruel ſtinging one I warrant him,
A loaden one: But what news of the Soldiers?
I did not like their parting, 'twas too ſullen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That they keep ſtill, and I fear a worſe clap:
They are drawn out of the Town, and ſtand in Counſels,
Hatching unquiet Thoughts, and cruel Purpoſes:
I went my ſelf unto 'em, talk'd with the Captains,
Whom I found fraught with nothing but loud Murmurs,
And deſperate Curſes, ſounding theſe words often
Like Trumpets to their Angers: we are ruin'd,
Our Services turn'd to Diſgraces, Miſchiefs,
Our brave old General, like one had pilfer'd,
Tortur'd and whipt: the Colonel's Eyes like Torches,
Blaze every where and fright fair Peace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yet worſe Sir:
The News is currant now, they mean to leave you,
Leave their Allegiance: and under Olins charge
The bloody Enemy march ſtrait againſt you.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I have heard this too, Sir:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This muſt be prevented,
And ſuddenly, and warily.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: 'Tis time, Sir,
But what to miniſter, or how?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Go in with me,
And there we'll think upon't: ſuch Blows as theſe,
Equal Defences ask, elſe they diſpleaſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Lord, what a Coile has here been with theſe Soldiers?
They are cruel Fellows.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: And yet methought we found 'em
Handſome enough; I'll tell thee true, Peteſca,
I look'd for other manner of Dealings from 'em,
And had prepar'd my ſelf; but where's my Lady?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: In her old Dumps within; monſtrous melancholy;
Sure ſhe was mad of this Wench.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: If ſhe had been a Man,
She would have been a great deal madder, I am glad ſhe is ſhifted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas a wicked thing for me to betray her,

And yet I muſt confeſs ſhe ſtood in our Lights.
Enter Alinda:
What young thing's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Good morrow beauteous Gentlewomen:
Pray you is the Princeſs ſtirring yet?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: He has her Face.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Her very Tongue, and Tone too; her Youth upon him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I gueſs you to be the Princeſs's Women.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes, we are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pray is there not a Gentlewoman waiting on her Grace,
You call Alinda?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Devil ſure in her ſhape.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I have heard her tell my Lady of a Brother,
An only Brother that ſhe had: in Travel —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Maſs, I remember that: this may be he too:

I would this thing would ſerve her.
Enter Olimpia.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: So would I, Wench,
We ſhould love him better ſure: Sir, here's the Princeſs,
She beſt can ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How I love that Preſence!
O bleſſed Eyes, how nobly ſhines your Comforts!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: We know not, Madam:
He ask'd us for your Grace: and as we gueſs it,
He is Alinda's Brother.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ha! let me mark him:
My Grief has almoſt blinded me: her Brother!
By Venus, he has all her Sweetneſs upon him:
Two ſilver drops of Dew were never liker.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Gracious Lady —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That pleaſant Pipe he has too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Being my Happineſs to paſs by this way,
And having, as I underſtand by Letters,
A Siſter in your vertuous Service, Madam —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O now my Heart, my Heart akes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All the Comfort
My poor Youth has, all that my Hopes have built me,
I thought it my firſt Duty, my beſt Service
Here to arrive firſt, humbly to thank your Grace
For my poor Siſter, humbly to thank your Nobleneſs,
That bounteous Goodneſs in you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis he certainly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That Spring of Favour to her: with my Life, Madam,
If any ſuch moſt happy Means might meet me,
To ſhew my Thankfulneſs.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What have I done, Fool?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She came a Stranger to your Grace, no Courtier;
Nor of that curious Breed befits your Service;
Yet one, I dare aſſure my Soul, that lov'd you
Before ſhe ſaw you; doated on your Vertues;
Before ſhe knew thoſe fair Eyes long'd to read 'em.
You only had her Prayers, you her Wiſhes;
And that one Hope to be yours once, preſerv'd her,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have done wickedly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little Beauty,
Such as a Cottage breeds, ſhe brought along with her;
And yet our Country-eyes eſteem'd it much too:
But for her beauteous Mind, forget, great Lady,
I am her Brother, and let me ſpeak a Stranger:
Since ſhe was able to beget a Thought, 'twas honeſt,
The daily Study how to fit your Services,
Truly to tread that vertuous Path you walk in,
So fir'd her honeſt Soul, we thought her Sainted;
I preſume ſhe is ſtill the ſame: I would fain ſee her;
For, Madam, 'tis no little Love I owe her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sir, ſuch a Maid there was, I had —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: There was, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O my poor Wench: Eyes, I will ever curſe you
For your Credulity, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's her Name, Madam,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Give me a little leave, Sir, to lament her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is ſhe dead, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dead, Sir, to my Service.
She is gone, pray ask me no farther.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I obey, Madam:
Gone? now muſt I lament too: ſaid you gone, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Gone, gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's a cruel Saying:
Her Honour too?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Prithee look angry on me,
And if thou ever lovedſt her, ſpit upon me;
Do ſomething like a Brother, like a Friend,
And do not only ſay thou lov'ſt her —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I ruin'd her, I wrong'd her, I abus'd her;
Poor innocent Soul, I flung her; ſweet Alinda,
Thou vertuous Maid, my Soul now calls thee vertuous.
Why do ye not rail now at me?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: For what, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Call me baſe treacherous Woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Raſhly I thought her falſe, and put her from me,
Raſhly, and madly I betray'd her Modeſty,
Put her to wander, Heaven knows where; nay, more, Sir,
Stuck a black Brand upon her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Twas not well, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Twas damnable; ſhe loving me ſo dearly,
Never poor Wench lov'd ſo: Sir, believe me,
'Twas the moſt dutious Wench, the beſt Companion;
When I was pleas'd, the happieſt, and the gladdeſt,
The modeſteſt ſweet Nature dwelt within her:
I ſaw all this, I knew all this, I lov'd it,
I doated on it too, and yet I kill'd it:
O what have I forſaken? what have I loſt?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, I'll take my leave, ſince ſhe is wandring,
'Tis fit I know no reſt.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Will you go too, Sir?
I have not wrong'd you yet, if you dare truſt me,
For yet I love Alinda there, I honour her,
I love to look upon thoſe Eyes that ſpeak her,
To read that Face again, Modeſty keep me,
Alinda, in that ſhape: but why ſhould you truſt me,
'Twas I betray'd your Siſter, I undid her;
And believe me, gentle Youth, 'tis I weep for her:
Appoint what Penance you pleaſe: but ſtay then,
And ſee me perform it: ask what Honour this Place
Is able to heap on you, or what Wealth:
If following me will pleaſe you, my Care of you,
Which for your Siſter's ſake, for your own Goodneſs —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not all the Honour-Earth has, now ſhe's gone, Lady,
Not all the Favour; yet if I ſought Preferment,
Under your bounteous Grace I would only take it.
Peace reſt upon you: one ſad Tear every Day
For poor Alinda's ſake, 'tis fit you pay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thouſand, noble Youth; and when I ſleep,
Even in my ſilver Slumbers ſtill I'll weep. Exit.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Have you been with 'em?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, an't pleaſe your Grace,
But no Perſuaſion ſerves 'em, nor no Promiſe,
They are fearful angry, and by this time, Sir,
Upon their March to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
They muſt be ſtopt.
Enter Burris.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I, but what Force is able? and what Leader!—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How now, have you been with Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes, and't pleaſe you,
And told him all: he frets like a chaf'd Lyon,
And calls for his Arms, and all thoſe honeſt Courtiers
That dare draw Swords.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is he able to do any thing?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: His Mind is well enough; and where his Charge is,
Let him be ne'er ſo ſore, 'tis a full Army.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who commands the Rebels?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: The young Colonel,
That makes the old Man almoſt mad: he ſwears, Sir,
He will not ſpare his Son's Head for the Dukedom.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is the Court in Arms?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As faſt as they can buſtle,
Every Man mad to go now: inſpir'd ſtrangely,
As if they were to force the Enemy.
I beſeech your Grace to give me leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Pray go, Sir,
And look to the old Man well; take up all fairly,
And let no Blood be ſpilt; take general Pardons,
And quench this Fury with fair Peace.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir,
Or ſeal it with my Service; they are Villains;
The Court is up: good Sir, go ſtrengthen 'em,
Your Royal Sight will make 'em ſcorn all Dangers;
The General needs no Proof.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, let's go view 'em. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE 4.
div.stage: Enter Theodore, Putskie, Ancient, Soldiers, with Drums and Colours.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis known we are up, and marching: no • ubmiſſion,
No Promiſe of baſe Peace can cure our Maladies,
We have ſuffer'd beyond all Repair of Honour:
Your valiant old Man's whipt; whipt, Gentlemen,
Whipt like a Slave: that Fleſh that never trembled,
Nor ſhrunk one Sinew at a thouſand Charges;
That noble Body rib'd in Arms, the Enemy
So often ſhook at, and then ſhunn'd like Thunder,
That Body's torn with Laſhes.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Let's turn Head.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Turn nothing, Gentlemen, let's march on fairly,
Unleſs they charge us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Think ſtill of his Abuſes,
And keep your Angers.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: He was whipt like a Top,
I never ſaw a Whore ſo lac'd: Court School butter?
Is this their Diet? I'll dreſs 'em one running Banquet:
What Oracle can alter us? Did not we ſee him?
See him we lov'd?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And though we did obey him,
Forc'd by his Reverence for that time, is't fit, Gentlemen?
My noble Friends, is't fit we Men, and Soldiers,
Live to endure this, and look on too?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Forward:
They may call back the Sun as ſoon, ſtay Time,
Preſcribe a Law to Death, as we endure this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They will make you all fair Promiſes.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We care not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Uſe all their Arts upon you.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Hang all their Arts.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: And happily they'll bring him with 'em.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: March apace then,
He is old and cannot overtake us.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Say he do.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We'll run away with him: they ſhall never ſee him more:
The Truth is, we'll hear nothing, ſtop at nothing,
Conſider nothing but our way; believe nothing,
Not though they ſay their Prayers: be content with nothing,
But the knocking our their Brains: and laſt, do nothing,
But ban 'em and curſe 'em, till we come to kill 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Remove them forwards bravely; keep your Minds whole,
And the next time we face 'em, ſhall be fatal. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Archas, Duke, Burris, Gentlemen, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Peace to your Grace; take reſt, they are before us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They are, Sir, and upon the March. [Ex. Du.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Lord Burris,
Take you thoſe Horſe and coaſt 'em: upon the firſt Advantage,
If they will not ſlack their March, charge 'em up roundly,
By that time I'll come in.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I'll do it truly. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How do you feel your ſelf, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, I thank you;
A little weak, but Anger ſhall ſupply that.
You will all ſtand bravely to it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whilſt we have Lives, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You ſpeak like Gentlemen; I'll make the Knaves know,
The proudeſt and the ſtrongeſt hearted Rebel,
They have a Law to live in, and they ſhall have;
Beat up a-pace, by this time he is upon 'em,
And Sword, but hold me now, thou ſhalt play ever. [Ex.

div.stage: Enter Drums beating, Theodore, Putskie, Ancient, and their Soldiers.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Stand, ſtand, ſtand cloſe and ſure;
The Horſe will charge us. [Enter Bur. and 1 or 2 Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Let 'em come on, we have Provender fit for 'em.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here comes Lord Burris, Sir, I think to parley.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are welcome, noble Sir, I hope to our part.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: No, valiant Colonel, I am come to chide you,
To pity you; to kill you, if theſe fail me;
Fie, what Diſhonour ſeek you? What black Infamy!
Why do you draw out thus? draw all Shame with you?
Are theſe fit Cares in Subjects? I command you
Lay down your Arms again, move in that Peace,
That fair Obedience you were bred in.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Charge us?
We come not here to argue.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Charge up bravely,
And hotly too, we have hot Spleens to meet you,
Hot as the Shames are offer'd us [Enter Arch. Gent. and Sold.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Look behind you,
Do you ſee that old Man? do you know him, Soldiers?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your Father, Sir, believe me —

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know his Marches,
You have ſeen his Executions: is it yet Peace?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We'll die here firſt.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Farewel: You'll hear on's preſently.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay, Burris: this is too poor, too beggarly a Body
To bear the Honour of a Charge from me,
A ſort of tatter'd Rebels; go provide Gallouſes;
You are troubled with hot Heads, I'll cool you preſently:
Theſe look like Men that were my Soldiers
Now I behold 'em nearly, and more narrowly,
