My honeſt Friends: where got they theſe fair Figures?
Where did they ſteal theſe Shapes?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are ſtruck already.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do you ſee that Fellow there; that goodly Rebel?
He looks as like a Captain I lov'd tenderly;
A Fellow of a Faith indeed.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: He has ſham'd him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And that that bears the Colours there, moſt certain
So like an Ancient of mine own, a brave Fellow,
A loving and obedient, that believe me, Burris,
I am amaz'd and troubled: and were it not
I know the general Goodneſs of my People,
The Duty, and the Truth, the ſtedfaſt Honeſty,
And am aſſur'd they would as ſoon turn Devils
As Rebels to Allegiance, for mine Honour.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Here needs no Wars.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I pray forgive us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Good General forgive us, or uſe your Sword,
Your Words are double Death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good noble General.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, be merciful.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Weep out your ſhames firſt,
You make me Fool for Company: Fie, Soldiers,
My Soldiers too, and play theſe Tricks. What's he there?
Sure I have ſeen his Face too; yes, moſt certain
I have a Son, but I hope he is not here now,
Would much reſemble this Man, wondrous near him,
Juſt of his height and making too; you ſeem a Leader.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good Sir, do not ſhame me more: I know your Anger,
And leſs than Death I look not for.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You ſhall be my Charge, Sir, it ſeems you want Foes,
When you would make your Friends your Enemies:
A running Blood you have, but I ſhall cure you.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Good Sir —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more, good Lord: beat forward, Soldiers:
And you, march in the Rear, you have loſt your Places.

div.head: SCENE VI.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You ſhall not be thus ſullen ſtill, with me, Siſter,
You do the moſt unnobly to be angry;
For as I have a Soul, I never touch'd her,
I never yet knew one unchaſt Thought in her:
I muſt confeſs I lov'd her; as who would not?
I muſt confeſs I doated on her ſtrangely,
I offer'd, all; yet ſo ſtrong was her Honour,
So fortify'd as fair, no Hope could reach her;
And whilſt the World beheld this, and confirm'd it,
Why would you be ſo jealous?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good Sir pardon me,
I feel ſufficiently my Follies Penance,
And am aſham'd, that Shame a thouſand Sorrows
Feed on continually. Would I had never ſeen her,
Or with a clearer Judgment look'd upon her:
She was too good for me, ſo heavenly good, Sir,
Nothing but Heaven can love that Soul ſufficiently,
Where I ſhall ſee her once again. [Enter Burris.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more Tears,
If ſhe be within the Dukedom, we'll recover her:
Welcome, Lord Burris, fair News I hope.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Moſt fair, Sir,
Without one Drop of Blood theſe Wars are ended,
The Soldier cool'd again, indeed aſham'd, Sir,
And all his Anger ended.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where's Lord Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not far off, Sir: with him his valiant Son,
Head of this Fire, but now a Priſoner;
And if by your ſweet Mercy not prevented,
I fear ſome fatal Stroke. [Drums.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I hear the Drums beat,
Welcome, my worthy Friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand where you are, Sir,
Even as you love your Country, move not forward,
Nor plead for Peace till I have done a Juſtice,
A Juſtice on this Villain; none of mine now,
A Juſtice on this Rebel.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O my Brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: This fatal Firebrand —

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forget not, old Man,
He is thy Son of thine own Blood.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: In theſe Veins
No treachery e'er harbour'd yet, no mutiny,
I ne'er gave life to lewd and headſtrong Rebels.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: 'Tis his firſt Fault.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not of a thouſand Sir,
Or were it ſo, it is a Fault ſo mighty.
So ſtrong againſt the Nature of all Mercy,
His Mother were ſhe living, would not weep for him;
He dare not ſay he would live.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I muſt not Sir,
Whilſt you ſay it is not fit: your Grace's mercy
Not to my life apply'd, but to my fault Sir,
The World's forgiveneſs next; laſt, on my Knees Sir,
I humbly beg,
Do not take from me yet the Name of Father,
Strike me a thouſand Blows, but let me dye yours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He moves my Heart: I muſt be ſuddain with him,
I ſhall grow faint elſe, in my Execution;
Come, come Sir, you have ſeen Death; now meet him bravely.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hold, hold I ſay, a little hold, conſider
Thou haſt no more Sons, Archas, to inherit thee:

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I have another, and a Nobler:
No Treaſon ſhall inherit me: young Archas
A Boy, as ſweet as young, my Brother breeds him,
My noble Brother Brisky, breeds him nobly,
Him let your favour find: give him your honour.

div.stage: Enter Putsky (alias Brisky) an d Alinda (alias Archas.)

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Thou haſt no Child left Ar chas, none to inherit thee
If thou ſtrik'ſt that ſtroke now: behold young Archas;
Behold thy Brother here, thou bloody Brother,
As bloody to this Sacrifice as thou art:
Heave up thy Sword, and mine's heav'd up: ſtrike Archas,
And I'll ſtrke too, as ſuddenly, as deadly:
Have Mercy, and I'll have Mercy: The Duke gives it,
Look upon all theſe, how they weep it from thee,
Chooſe quickly, and begin.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: On your Obedience,
On your Allegiance ſave him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take him to you, [Sold. ſhout.
And ſirrah, be an honeſt Man, you have reaſon:
I thank ye worthy Brother; welcome Child,
Mine one ſweet Child.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why was this Boy concealed thus?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your Grace's Pardon:
Fearing the Vow you made againſt my Brother
And that your Anger would not only light
On him, but find out all his Family,
This Young Boy, to preſerve from after danger,
Like a young Wench, hither I brought; my ſelf
In the Habit of an ordinary Captain
Diſguis'd, got Entertainment, and ſerv'd here
That I might ſtill be ready to all Fortunes:
The Boy your Grace took, nobly entertain'd him,
But thought a Girl, Alinda, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Stand away,
And let me look upon him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My young Miſtriſs?
This is a ſtrange Metamorphoſis, Alinda,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your Graces humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hither Siſter:
I dare yet ſcarce believe mine Eyes? how they view one another?
Doſt thou not love this Boy well?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I ſhould lye elſe,
Truſt me, extreamly lye Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Didſt thou never wiſh Olimpia,
It might be thus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here take him:
Nay, do not bluſh: I do not jeſt; kiſs ſweetly:
Boy, you kiſs faintly Boy; Heaven give you Comfort:
Teach him, he'll quickly learn: there's two Hearts eas'd now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You do me too much honour Sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No Archas,
But all I can, I will; can you love me? ſpeak truly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes Sir, dearly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hither Viola, can you Love this Man?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'll do the beſt I can Sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Seal it Burris:
We'll all to Church together inſtantly:
And then a Vie for Boys; ſtay, bring Borosky. Enter Borosky
I had almoſt forgot that lump of Miſchief.
There Archas, take the Enemy to honour,
The Knave to worth: do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then to my Sword again; you to your Prayers;
Waſh off your Villanies, you feel the Burthen.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Forgive me 'ere I die, moſt honeſt Archas;
'Tis too much honour that I periſh thus;
O ſtrike my Faults to kill them that no Memory,
No black and blaſted Infamy hereafter—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And truly penitent, to make your way ſtraight?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Thus I waſh off my Sins

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand up, and live then,
And live an honeſt Man; I ſcorn Mens ruine:
Take him again. Sir, try him: and believe
This thing will be a perfect Man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I take him.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And when I fail thoſe Hopes, Heaven's Hopes fail me.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You are old: no more Wars Father:
Theodore take you the Charge, be General.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: All good Bleſs you.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: And my good Father, you dwell in my Boſom,
From you riſe all my good Thoughts: when I would think
And examine Time for one that's fairly Noble,
And the ſame Man through all the ſtraights of Vertue,
Upon this Silver Book I'll look, and read him.
Now forward merrily to Hymens Rights,
To Joys and Revels, Sports, and he that can
Moſt honour Archas, is the nobleſt Man. Exeunt.

div.p: Lately Printed the Northern Laſs; or, The Neſt of Fools. The Royal Merchant; or, Beggars Buſh. Both Comedies.
